both this was a big problem because our client was heavily invested in the Android platform in another country

collectors one for net and one for Java these collectors handled objects
differently and on different timelines so once we understood this we
changed our approach instead of constantly redrawing our screen which is what happens at least at the time it did
um every time I wanted to show a new menu or a new screen we just reused objects and updated the content within
it that solved our crashing problem but here's where it gets worse in my desperation to fix the issue I had tried
switching between garbage collectors and even attempted to write my own like through this whole process Pro tip don't

you through this mobile architecture decision tree that I came up with or mad tree for short it's a simple yet
powerful tool that helps you decide which mobile development approach is best for your current project because
remember you should decide this based on the project not just because it's what you're comfortable with although that
could be a factor this tree asks four key questions
are you on a tight budget does it need constant internet activity connectivity to work at all will it have offline
functionality will it need to access device features like cameras and it kind of guides you in the direction you need
to go native is best for apps that need full device feature access and offline functionality but it's typically more
expensive to build because you need twice as much time crossplatform compile is a good middle ground that it can
access device features and work offline while potentially being more cost-effective than native development
hybrid web view is suitable for apps that don't need extensive device features but still requires some offline
functionality and the ability to be in the App Store it's often more budget friendly and of course the most cost-
effective one should be mobile web ideal for projects that mainly require connectivity and don't need any device
specific features or offline functionality this tree is a guide not a strict rule but I get asked these
questions all the time and I figure that this might be a nice little graph for you the beauty of this diagram is its
flexibility it helps you just consider things and I often will go back and look at it myself for the next
project some parting advice you must plan your approach small or large you
have to plan it you have to you can be agile but some initial planning is
crucial know that your app's purpose is going to be this and have a rough idea of screen layouts before you even start
with the very first one if I'm developing um an app that is
going to be more immersive I'll go native every time why because performance is critical when you're
constantly challenging the phone's graphic card you need that and if this is your first mobile
app just create a proof of concept it doesn't need to be elaborate just aim to build something keep it small and to the
point and not large allow room for growth not complexity be mindful of how much you're
using the internet allow several weeks for app submissions measure 10 times and
submit your app once because rejections are Swift and sometimes hard to reverse course stress tanks stress tests on low
